{{Year nav topic5|2016|chess}} Major [[chess]] events that took place in 2016 included the [[Women's World Chess Championship 2016]] between [[Mariya Muzychuk]] and [[Hou Yifan]], won by Hou Yifan, and the [[Candidates Tournament 2016|Candidates Tournament]], won by [[Sergey Karjakin]], who challenged [[Magnus Carlsen]] in the [[World Chess Championship 2016]]. {{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox Stadium | name = Bellslea Park | nickname = | image = [[Image:Bellslea Park.jpg|250px]] | caption = Bellslea Park, overlooked by Fraserburgh South Kirk | fullname = | former_names = | location = Seaforth Street, [[Fraserburgh]],
[[Aberdeenshire]], [[Scotland]] | broke_ground = | built = 1909 | opened = | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Fraserburgh F.C.]] | operator = | surface = | cost = | architect = | capacity = 1,800 (480 seats) | record_attendance = 5,800 v [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Heart of Midlothian]]
13 February 1954 | dimensions = 109 x 66 yards | acreage = | tenants = [[Fraserburgh F.C.]] (1910–present) | website = }} '''Bellslea Park''' is a [[association football|football]] ground in [[Fraserburgh]] in north-east [[Scotland]], which is the home ground of [[Highland Football League]] side [[Fraserburgh F.C.]]. It is located on Seaforth Street in the centre of the town and has a capacity of 3,000 with 480 seated.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-north-east-orkney-shetland-42896899 |title=Fraserburgh match lock-out over 'counterfeit tickets' |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=31 January 2018 |accessdate=1 February 2018}} ==History== [[Fraserburgh F.C.]] was formed in 1910 and have always played their home games at Bellslea Park. Prior to when the football club played their games at the ground, the site was a [[park|public park]] and hosted football games of other local clubs from around the town. In 1909, maintenance work began and a perimeter wall was added around the site. The first match played on the ground was in December 1909 in a match between Fraserburgh Thistle and [[Ellon United F.C.|Ellon United]] in the [[Aberdeenshire Cup]].[http://www.fraserburghfc.net/history.html Fraserburgh Football Club History] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206021609/http://www.fraserburghfc.net/history.html |date=6 February 2012 }}, [[Fraserburgh F.C.]]. Retrieved 20 May 2012. Fraserburgh's record attendance at Bellslea Park came in February 1954 when 5,800 spectators watched the club take on [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Heart of Midlothian]] of [[Edinburgh]] in the [[1953-54 Scottish Cup#Second round|second round]] of the [[Scottish Cup]]. The home side lost 3–0 to the top division side.[http://www.highlandfootballleague.com/clubs/Showclub.aspx?id=8 Fraserburgh F.C.], [[Highland Football League|The Scottish Highland Football League]]. Retrieved 20 May 2012. ==Transport== The nearest railway station to the ground is in [[Aberdeen]], around {{convert|37.5|mi|km|1}} to the south of the town. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/venues/scotland/bellslea-park/ Bellslea Park at soccerway.com] {{Football venues in Scotland}} {{Coord|57|41|24.08|N|2|0|14.29|W|type:landmark_scale:2000_region:GB|display=title}} [[Category:Highland Football League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Aberdeenshire]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1909]] [[Category:Fraserburgh]]

{{Football club infobox | clubname = Brigade Boys| image = [[Image:Brigade Boys Club.png|300px|Logo]] | fullname = Brigade Boys Club | nickname = | founded = | ground = [[Dasarath Rangasala Stadium]],
[[Kathmandu]], [[Nepal]] | capacity = 25,000| chairman = | manager = | league = [[Nepal A- Division League]] | season = 2005-06 | position = | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1=| leftarm1=ff0000|body1=ff0000|rightarm1=ff0000|shorts1=FFFFFF|socks1=ff0000| }} '''Brigade Boys Club''' is a [[Nepal]]ese [[football (soccer)|football]] club from [[Patan, Lalitpur|Lalitpur]], which plays in the town of [[Kathmandu]]. They play in the Nepalese first division, the [[Nepal A- Division League]]. ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100706155304/http://brigadeboysfc.com/ Brigade Boys FC] {{Football in Nepal}} {{Martyr's Memorial B-Division League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Nepal]] {{Nepal-footyclub-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox venue | name = CC Amfi | nickname = ''Fjøset'' ("The Barn") | image = [[File:Hamar Olympic Amfi 2006.JPG|300px]] | caption = CC Amfi (right) and Storhamar Ishall in March 2006 | fullname = Nordlyshallen | location = [[Storhamar]], [[Hamar]], [[Norway]] | coordinates = {{coord|60.8010588|11.0383415|type:landmark_region:NO-04|format=dms|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 25 November 1992 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Hamar Municipality]] | operator = Hamar Olympiske Anlegg | surface = | construction_cost = {{NOK|83 million}} | architect = [[HRTB]] | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre (1992-2015) | tenants = [[Storhamar Ishockey]] (1992-present)
[[Storhamar Yngres]] (2016-present) | capacity = 7,500 | dimensions = | scoreboard = | publictransit = '''Bus''': Line B2 }} '''CC Amfi''', also known as '''Nordlyshallen''' ("The Northern Light Hall") is an indoor sports [[arena]] in [[Hamar]], [[Norway]]. It is mostly used for [[ice hockey]] and is the home arena of [[Storhamar Hockey]]. It has also been used for [[short track speed skating]], [[figure skating]], [[team handball|handball]], events and concerts. The venue has a capacity for 7,000 spectators and was built for the [[1994 Winter Olympics]], where it was used for [[short track speed skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics|short track speed skating]] and [[figure skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics|figure skating]]. Other major events held at the arena include the [[1999 IIHF World Championship]] in ice hockey, the [[1999 World Women's Handball Championship]], the [[2012 IPC Ice Sledge Hockey World Championships]] and the [[2016 Winter Youth Olympics]]. Construction of CC Amfi started in August 1991 and it was inaugurated on 25 November 1992, with construction costing 83 million [[Norwegian krone]] (NOK). The venues are owned by Hamar Olympiske Anlegg, a subsidiary of [[Hamar Municipality]]. ==History== [[File:Hamar OL-Amfi.jpg|thumb|left|June 2011 exterior view of Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre]] ===The Olympic venue=== In the unsuccessful [[Lillehammer bid for the 1992 Winter Olympics]], ice hockey events were proposed played in Hamar and [[Gjøvik]]. However, in the [[Lillehammer bid for the 1994 Winter Olympics]], all ice events were moved to [[Lillehammer]] proper,{{cite web|url=http://www.lillehammer.kommune.no/links/113598 |title=An Olympic Fairy Tale |last=Hove-Ødegård |first=Arne |last2=Celius |first2=Sten |last3=Brun |first3=Ivar Ole |publisher=Lillehammer Municipality |year=2004 |accessdate=11 December 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uv6grx5a?url=http://www.lillehammer.kommune.no/files/75261/ |archivedate=12 December 2010 |page=9 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} after recommendations from the [[International Ice Hockey Federation]], who wanted all the ice hockey events to take place in the same town. This would involve building two temporary ice rinks at [[Stampesletta]] in Lillehammer, and after the Olympics moving them to Gjøvik and either [[Moelv]], [[Brumunddal]] or [[Kongsvinger]]. By 1989, the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) decided to include short-track speed skating, increasing the number of ice halls from two to three. In April, the [[Lillehammer Olympic Organizing Committee]] (LOOC) therefore proposed building permanent ice rinks in Hamar and Gjøvik.{{cite news |title=Også OL-status til Hamar og Gjøvik? |last=Dehlin |first=Håkon |date=5 April 1989 |page=44 |work=[[Aftenposten]] |language=Norwegian}} The IOC also required that the long-track speed skating be done indoors. Hamar was awarded the venue, [[Vikingskipet]], after Hamar Municipality guaranteed to cover all costs exceeding NOK 200 million. This provided sufficient leverage for Hamar to host additional events. LOOC approved the construction of Vikingskipet in on 15 December 1989 and at the same time supported proposals to renovate Storhamar Ishall to host Olympic ice hockey matches. A second, temporary training rink was also planned built in Hamar.{{cite news |title=Uendret kostnadsramme for Lillehammer-OL, tautrekking ventes på høyt plan |agency=[[Norwegian News Agency]] |last=Mathisen |first=Pål |date=15 December 1989 |language=Norwegian}}{{cite news |title=– Står fast på 6,4 mrd. |work=[[Aftenposten]] |language=Norwegian |last=Larsen |first=Gunnar Tore |last2= Kirkebøen |first2=Stein |last3=Fagerli |first3=Hans Petter |date=16 December 1989 |page=30}} In addition, the Hamar venue would be used for short track speed skating, while figure skating would be run in Lillehammer.{{cite news |title=Skøyte-komite anbefaler kortbane-løp på Hamar, kunstløp i Håkons Hall |agency=[[Norwegian News Agency]] |last=Mathisen |first=Pål |date=10 January 1990 |language=Norwegian}} In March, the plans were changed, so Hamar would receive an all-new ice rink in addition to a renovation of Storhamar Ishall.{{cite news |title=Ishockeypresident: – Trist og glad! |work=[[Aftenposten]] |last=Siem |first=Kjetil |authorlink=Kjetil Siem |date=22 March 1990 |page=36}} Financing of the venue was officially granted by the [[Parliament of Norway]] in April 1990.LOOC (III): 57 The [[International Skating Union]] wanted to locate all skating in Hamar, and in October 1990, LOOC confirmed that they would reallocate the events so that all the all skating events would take place in Hamar, and that a separate Olympic Village would be built in Hamar for skaters.{{cite news |title=OL-kunstløp til Hamar? |last=Larsen |first=Gunnar Tore |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=9 October 1990 |page=35 |language=Norwegian}} The original plans for the Olympic Amphitheatre called for a capacity for 4,500 and construction to cost NOK 65. By June 1991, LOOC decided to increase the size of the venue, as IOC would only allow the venue host figure skating if its spectator capacity was raised to 6,000.{{cite news |title=Hamar Ishall blir større og dyrere |agency=[[Norwegian News Agency]] |date=18 June 1991 |language=Norwegian}} Financing of the expansion was granted in August, with the cost rising to NOK 83.3 million.{{cite news |title=Hamar får OL-kunstløp |last=Gravdal |first=Gunn |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=6 August 1991 |page=4 |language=Norwegian}} Early plans called for the venue to be built in concrete, but a research project coordinated by the [[Norwegian Institute of Technology]] made it possible to cover the venue's exterior and interior in wood panel. This solution was hailed as aesthetical by architects, and as a technical innovation by the Norwegian construction industry.{{cite news |title=Det "lille" mesterverk på Hamar |work=[[Aftenposten]] |last=Gravdal |first=Gunn |date=10 November 1992 |page=13}} The contract to build the venue was awarded to Martin M. Bakken, a local contractor, and construction started in August 1991.{{cite news |title=Byggestart for det siste OL-anlegget |agency=[[Norwegian News Agency]] |date=5 August 1991 |language=Norwegian}} The [[laminated wood]] beams for the roof were delivered by [[Moelven Industrier]].{{cite news |title=Ny OL-kontrakt til Moelven |last=Gravdal |first=Gunn |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=19 August 1992 |page=23 |language=Norwegian}} Ice was laid on the on 12 November 1992{{cite news |title=Den første puck på olympisk is |work=[[Aftenposten]] |last=Gravdal |first=Gunn |date=13 November 1992 |page=6 |language=Norwegian}} and the arena was officially completed on 1 December.{{cite news |title=Anleggene |date=21 February 1982 |language=Norwegian |page=18 |work=[[Aftenposten]]}} The opening show took place already on 25 November and the first official match, between Storhamar and [[Stjernen Hockey|Stjernen]], took place on 8 December. The venue was the 26th indoor ice hockey arena in Norway. After the Olympic arena was built, Storhamar Ishall was renovated, and the spectator capacity reduced through the construction of storage facilities and VIP areas. The Olympic Amphitheatre later installed Norway's first [[scoreboard|media cube]] in 2004.{{cite web |url=http://www.dragons.no/content.asp?menuItem=0&docID=14379&docDetail=on&docType=A |title=Multimediakube på plass i Hamar OL-Amfi |publisher=[[Storhamar Dragons]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=9 May 2005 |archivedate=9 February 2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050209101114/http://www.dragons.no/content.asp?menuItem=0&docID=14379&docDetail=on&docType=A}} The arena was formerly known as '''Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre''' ({{lang-no|Hamar OL-Amfi}} or {{lang|no|Hamar Olympiske Amfi}}) until October 2015, when [[CC Stadion|CC]] bought the naming rights for the arena. A new media cube was also installed as part of the deal.{{cite web |url=http://www.sil.no/2015/10/06/cc-kjoper-hallnavnet-og-ny-kube/ |title=CC kjøper hallnavnet, og ny kube! |work=[[Sil.no]] |last= |first= |date=6 October 2015 |page= |language=Norwegian}} ===Storhamar Ishall=== {{Infobox venue | name = Storhamar Ishall | nickname = | image = | caption = | fullname = | location = [[Storhamar]], [[Hamar]], [[Norway]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = August 1981 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Hamar Municipality]] | operator = Hamar Olympiske Anlegg | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = [[HRTB]] | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Storhamar IL]] (1992-present)
[[2016 Winter Youth Olympics]] | capacity = 1,200 | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} Adjacent to the Olympic venue lays '''Storhamar Ishall'''. Solely used for ice hockey, it opened in 1981 and has a capacity for 1,200. Since the opening of the Olympic venue, Storhamar Ishall has been used for training, and the two rinks share common dressing rooms and other facilities. The sport of ice hockey was taken up by [[Storhamar IL]] after the [[1952 Winter Olympics]] in [[Oslo]] spurred the public interest in the sport. The pitch used by the club for summer sports was iced for the winter and surrounded with {{convert|15|cm|sp=us|adj=on}} tall wooden boards. As the club established an ice hockey section in 1955 it received funding from the [[Norwegian Ice Hockey Federation]] to purchase {{convert|120|cm|sp=us|adj=on}} tall boards. The pitch was renovated for NOK 4,000 in 1957, financed through a municipal grant. Among the upgrades was insulation of the club house, which was a barracks stemming from the [[Second World War]]. A contractor who had a storage facility close by, kept receiving visits from juveniles who jumped the fence and took material for the work. He eventually visited the club house and supplied them with a key to the facility, somewhat involuntarily becoming the club's first sponsor.Gjerdåker (1998): 221 Storhamar traditionally played ice hockey on natural ice. In 1977, the club was promoted to the First Division, where the regulations required that the team play on [[artificial ice]]. To avoid having to play all their games [[road (sport)|on the road]], the municipality agreed to finance an outdoor artificial rink at Storhamar. With the increased attendance and interest for hockey following the town's team playing in the top league, Storhamar started planning an indoor venue.Gjerdåker (1998): 224 State grants and a municipal guarantee were secured in 1980, with construction starting in the fall. The arena was built around the existing artificial rink.{{cite web|url=http://www.dragons.no/klubben/ishallene/ |title=Ishallene |author=[[Storhamar Dragons]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63sGyazkF?url=http://www.dragons.no/klubben/ishallene/ |archivedate=12 December 2011 |accessdate=12 December 2011 |language=Norwegian |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Because the hall could not be completed in time for the 1980–81 season, Storhamar was permitted to play the season in the Second Division. Storhamar Ishall became the [[list of indoor ice rinks in Norway|11th indoor ice hockey rink in Norway]]{{cite web|url=http://www.hockey.no/t2.asp?p=61305 |title=Ishaller |author=[[Norwegian Ice Hockey Association]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706024852/http://www.hockey.no/t2.asp?p=61305 |archivedate=6 July 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011 |language=Norwegian |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} when it opened in August 1981. The venue was to be partially financed through renting it out during the summer, including to an annual town fair. These ideas fell through and the municipality was forced to take over the venue. ==Facilities== The twin areas are located at [[Storhamar]], a residential area west of the town center of Hamar. Similar to Vikingskipet, the venue has two official names, Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre and Nordlyshallen. The former cannot be used commercially by non-Olympic events, such as in merchandise.{{cite news |title=Forvirring om bruk av navn på OL-arenaer |agency=[[Norwegian News Agency]] |language=Norwegian |date=2 September 1992}} The venue is owned by the municipally owned entity called Hamar Olympiske Anlegg, which also owns and operates Vikingskipet. The operating deficits are covered by a post-Olympic capital fund, which in the case of the two Hamar venues was NOK 60 million. Only the interest of these funds is used to operate the facilities, unlike Lillehammer and Gjøvik which also derive fundings from their base capital. Owing to the fund, Hamar Municipality does not need to give municipal grants to operate the facilities.{{cite news |title=Hamar bruker ikke én krone på OL-anleggene |work=[[Aftenposten]] |last=Larsen |first=Gunnar Tore |date=20 November 1998 |page=46 |language=Norwegian}} Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre is oval and has wood as the main construction material, both for the interior and the exterior.Hals (1999): 28 Overall it is {{convert|95|m|sp=us}} long, {{convert|75|m|sp=us}} wide and {{convert|22|m|sp=us}} tall.LOOC (III): 59 Architect Ola Mowè of [[HRTB]] chose the shape to connect various spatial designs and types of buildings in the neighborhood. The dark color was chosen to counteract the otherwise lively array of colors in the surroundings. The roof was built using laminated wood [[lattice girder]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.hrtb.no/prosjekter/ku_hamar.html |title=Hamar Olympiske Amfi |author=[[HRBT]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63sLGnPD4?url=http://www.hrtb.no/prosjekter/ku_hamar.html |archivedate=12 December 2011 |accessdate=12 December 2011 |language=Norwegian |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} The longest beam span is {{convert|70|m|sp=us}}. The exterior walls are clad with boards, panels and decorative [[molding (decorative)|molding]]. The interior wall are covered with [[pine]] panel. The surface area of the building is {{convert|11000|m2|sp=us}}, of which {{convert|7000|m2|sp=us}} is on the ground floor. When used for ice hockey, the venue has an official spectator capacity for 7,000.{{cite news |url=http://www.h-a.no/sport/dragons/--haaper-vi-bikker-5000-kanskje-6000-tilskuere |title=- Håper vi bikker 5.000, kanskje 6.000 tilskuere |work=[[Hamar Arbeiderblad]] |date=9 September 2016 |accessdate=9 September 2016 }} When used for handball the capacity is 6,480.{{cite news|url=http://www.vg.no/sport/haandball/artikkel.php?artid=2032643 |title=Hamar OL-Amfi |work=[[Verdens Gang]] |date=18 November 1999 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611213439/http://www.vg.no/sport/haandball/artikkel.php?artid=2032643 |archivedate=11 June 2011 |accessdate=12 December 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Storhamar Ishall has standing-only capacity for 1,500 spectators. During the Olympics, the main hall had 330 VIP seats, 60 seats for commentators and 200 press seats. The main rink had a new media cube installed in 2016. [[File:Hamar OL-Amfi indoor.jpg|thumb|center|600px|[[Storhamar Dragons]] playing [[Frisk Tigers]] during the [[2007–08 GET-ligaen season|2007–08 Norwegian Play-Off Finals]]]] ==Events== [[File:Stamp of Azerbaijan 297.jpg|thumb|upright|left|[[Nancy Kerrigan]] during the [[1994 Winter Olympics]]]] ===Olympics=== During the 1994 Winter Olympics, Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre was used for [[figure skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics|figure skating]] and [[short track speed skating]]. It hosted 13 events, drawing an average of 5,554 spectators.Eriksen and Greve (1995): 8 Storhamar Ishall was used for warming up and training to these events.Eriksen and Greve (1995): 37 Short track speed skating was dominated by [[South Korea at the 1994 Winter Olympics|South Korea]], who won four of the six events.{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/winter/1994/STK/ |title=Short Track Speed Skating at the 1994 Lillehammer Winter Games |publisher=Sports Reference |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uvmUgO1k?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/winter/1994/STK/ |archivedate=12 December 2010 |accessdate=12 December 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} [[Chae Ji-Hoon]] won the [[Short track speed skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics – Men's 500 metres|men's 500 meters]] and [[Kim Ki-Hoon]] the [[Short track speed skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics – Men's 1000 metres|1000 meters]],{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/winter/1994/STK/mens-1000-metres.html |title=Short Track Speed Skating at the 1994 Lillehammer Winter Games: Men's 1,000 metres |publisher=Sports Reference |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uvnGQo9u?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/winter/1994/STK/mens-1000-metres.html |archivedate=12 December 2010 |accessdate=12 December 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} while the [[Short track speed skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics – Men's 5000 metre relay|men's 5000 meter relay]] was won by [[Italy at the 1994 Winter Olympics|Italy]].{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/winter/1994/STK/mens-5000-metres-relay.html |title=Short Track Speed Skating at the 1994 Lillehammer Winter Games: Men's 5,000 metres Relay |publisher=Sports Reference |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uvlLM5Kx?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/winter/1994/STK/mens-5000-metres-relay.html |archivedate=12 December 2010 |accessdate=12 December 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} [[Cathy Turner]] defended her 1992 gold on the [[Short track speed skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics – Women's 500 metres|500 meters]],{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/winter/1994/STK/womens-500-metres.html |title=Short Track Speed Skating at the 1994 Lillehammer Winter Games: Women's 500 metres |publisher=Sports Reference |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uvnYAyN3?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/winter/1994/STK/womens-500-metres.html |archivedate=12 December 2010 |accessdate=12 December 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} while [[Chun Lee-Kyung]] won the [[Short track speed skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics – Women's 1000 metres|women's 1000 meters]] and South Korea won the [[Short track speed skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics – Women's 3000 metre relay|3000 meter relay]]. At 13, [[Kim Yun-Mi (speed skater)|Kim Yoon-Mi]] became the world's youngest Olympic gold medalist.{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/winter/1994/STK/womens-3000-metres-relay.html |title=Short Track Speed Skating at the 1994 Lillehammer Winter Games:Women's 3,000 metres Relay |publisher=Sports Reference |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uvnueupb?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/winter/1994/STK/womens-3000-metres-relay.html |archivedate=12 December 2010 |accessdate=12 December 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} In figure skating, relaxation of the [[amateurism]] rules led to several former stars returning.{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/winter/1994/FSK/mixed-ice-dancing.html |title=Figure Skating at the 1994 Lillehammer Winter Games: Mixed Ice Dancing |publisher=Sports Reference |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uwimz6pv?url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/winter/1994/FSK/mixed-ice-dancing.html |archivedate=13 December 2010 |accessdate=12 December 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The [[Figure skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics – Ladies' singles|ladies' singles]] has resulted in the as-yet highest United States Winter Olympic television viewership,{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2010/03/01/190-million-people-watched-olympics-in-us-2nd-most-watched-winter-olympics-in-history/43448 |title=190 million People watched Olympics, 2nd most watched winter Olympics in history |work=TV By the Numbers |date=1 March 2010 |first=Robert |last=Seidman |archivedate=13 December 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uxM6TbXq?url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2010/03/01/190-million-people-watched-olympics-in-us-2nd-most-watched-winter-olympics-in-history/43448 |accessdate=13 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} thanks to [[Tonya Harding|Tonya Harding's]] ex-husband Jeff Gillooly hiring Shane Stant to club fellow female figure skater [[Nancy Kerrigan]] in the knee.{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1004829/index.htm |last=Swift |first=E. M. |title=Anatomy of a Plot |work=Sports Illustrated |date=14 February 1994 |accessdate=11 December 2012 |archivedate=11 December 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63rQ8l2W0?url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1004829/index.htm |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The ladies' singles was won by [[Ukraine at the 1994 Winter Olympics|Ukraine]]'s [[Oksana Baiul]],LOOC (IV): 148 while the [[Figure skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics – Men's singles|men's singles]] was won by [[Russia at the 1994 Winter Olympics|Russia]]'s [[Alexei Urmanov]],LOOC (IV): 147 the [[Figure skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics – Ice dancing|ice dancing]] was won by Russians [[Oksana Grishuk]] and [[Evgeny Platov]] and the [[Figure skating at the 1994 Winter Olympics – Pair skating|pair skating]] was won by Russians [[Ekaterina Gordeeva]] and [[Sergei Grinkov]].LOOC (IV): 145 ===Ice hockey=== The Olympic Amphitheatre is the home venue of Storhamar Hockey, formerly known as the [[Storhamar Dragons]], the ice hockey division of [[Storhamar IL]]. The clubs' youth groups train in Storhamar Ishall, which is also used by the club's [[bandy]] group.{{cite news|url=http://www.h-a.no/Sport/Storhamar/tabid/96/Default.aspx?articleView=true&ModuleId=140091 |title=Vurderer håndball i ishallen |work=[[Hamar Dagblad]] |year=1999 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63sYPT1Bt?url=http://www.h-a.no/Sport/Storhamar/tabid/96/Default.aspx?articleView=true&ModuleId=140091 |archivedate=12 December 2011 |accessdate=12 December 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }} The Dragons have played continuously in the [[GET-ligaen|Elite League]] since the 1982–83 season. Their highest average league attendance was in the 1994–95 season, when they drew 3,731 spectators. While playing in Storhamar Ishall, the highest average attendance was in the 1984–85 season, with 2,097 spectators. From the 1991–92 to the following season, when the Olympic venue opened, the Dragons' average attendance doubled, from 1,412 to 2,875.{{cite web |url=http://www.dragons.no/klubben/historikk/sesonger/ |title=Storhamar Dragons sesong for sesong |publisher=[[Storhamar Dragons]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63sGIpZb8?url=http://www.dragons.no/klubben/historikk/sesonger/ |language=Norwegian |archivedate=12 December 2011 |accessdate=12 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} The Dragons' best attendance is 7,405, set during [[game seven]] of the [[2004–05 UPC-ligaen season|2004–05 Playoffs]], where the Dragons beat [[Vålerenga Ishockey|Vålerenga]] in [[overtime (ice hockey)|overtime]].{{cite news |title=Tidenes drama |last=Langholm |first=Dag |work=[[Verdens Gang]] |date=29 March 2004 |page=26 |language=Norwegian}} [[File:Stamp of Azerbaijan 296.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Alexei Urmanov]] during the 1994 Winter Olympics]] After the opening of Storhamar Ishall, it was used for two [[Norway men's national ice hockey team]] matches. On 2 January 1982, Norway lost 3–5 against [[Romania men's national ice hockey team|Romania]];{{cite news |title=TV-missen tente Norge |work=[[Verdens Gang]] |page=10 |date=4 January 1982 |language=Norwegian |last=Langholm |first=Dag}} and on 13 September 1983, Norway beat [[Italy men's national ice hockey team|Italy]] 4–2.{{cite news |title=Hockeystart som gir løfter: 4–2 |last=Dehlin |first=Håkon |date=14 September 1983 |language=Norwegian |page=34 |work=[[Aftenposten]]}} The venue hosted, along with Lillehammer, Group A of the [[1992 IIHF European U18 Championship]]. Norway's senior inaugural international match at the Olympic arena saw Norway lose 4–6 against [[Canada men's national ice hockey team|Canada]] on 9 February 1993.{{cite news |title=Ishockey: Norge – Canada |agency=[[Norwegian News Agency]] |language=Norwegian |date=9 February 1993}} The [[1999 IIHF World Championship]] in ice hockey was hosted at Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre, [[Håkons Hall]] in Lillehammer and [[Jordal Amfi]] in Oslo. Fourteen group-stage matches were held in Hamar.{{cite news |url=http://vg.no/sport/ishockey/vm99/kampene.hbs |title=VM-programmet |work=[[Verdens Gang]] |year=1999 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051126100831/http://vg.no/sport/ishockey/vm99/kampene.hbs |archivedate=26 November 2005 |accessdate=12 December 2010}} ====The longest game==== On March 12, 2017 Storhamar hosted the Sparta Warriors in game five of the quarter finals in the Elite league. The game lasted for 217 minutes and 14 seconds in what is believed to be the longest hockey game in history.https://www.nhl.com/news/incredible-hockey-game-in-norway-goes-8-overtimes/c-287656214 Joakim Jensen scored the game-winning goal as Storhamar won 2-1 after nearly 11 periods of play. ===In fiction=== In the film, ''[[I, Tonya]]'', the scenes which take place in CC Amfi have not been shot in Hamar, but in the [[Macon Coliseum]] in Georgia{{cite web|url=http://www.dga.org/~/media/Files/Production%20List/CPLBAFull%20pdf.pdf?531|title=Georgia: I, Tonya|website=[[Directors Guild of America]]|accessdate=January 16, 2017}}{{cite news|title=The Tonya Harding movie starring Margot Robbie is filming in Macon, GA next week|url=http://www.onlocationvacations.com/2017/01/25/tonya-harding-movie-starring-margot-robbie-filming-macon-ga-next-week/|accessdate=February 7, 2017|work=On Location Vacations|date=January 25, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Corley|first1=Laura|title="I, Tonya" films in Macon, bringing ’90s vibe to Macon Coliseum|url=http://www.macon.com/news/local/article130196134.html|accessdate=February 7, 2017|work=Macon|date=February 1, 2017|language=en}}. ===Other events=== Storhamar Ishall is the regular training venue for Storhamar IL's figure skating group.{{cite web |url=http://www.storhamar-kunstlop.com/skoyteskolen.html |title=Skøyteskolen |publisher=[[Storhamar IL]] |accessdate=11 December 2011 |archivedate=11 December 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63rOj7twR?url=http://www.storhamar-kunstlop.com/skoyteskolen.html |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Between them, the two venues have hosted the [[Norwegian Figure Skating Championships]] three times: Storhamar Ishall in [[1983 Norwegian Figure Skating Championships|1983]], and the Olympic Amphitheatre in [[2005 Norwegian Figure Skating Championships|2005]]{{cite web |url=http://www.n-s-f.no/kunstlop/statistikk/vis_nmstat.asp |title=NM-historikk kunstløp |publisher=[[Norwegian Skating Association]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=11 December 2011 |archivedate=11 December 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63qpYeuad?url=http://ww2.isu.org/figure/events/9900/jgp79900.html |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} and [[2011 Norwegian Figure Skating Championships|2011]].{{cite web |url=http://www.storhamar-kunstlop.com/NM2011.html |title=LM/NN Hamar 2011 |publisher=[[Storhamar IL]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=11 December 2011 |archivedate=11 December 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63qqNrTLD?url=http://www.storhamar-kunstlop.com/NM2011.html |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} In October 1993, the Olympic Amphitheatre hosted Piruetten 1993, a pre-Olympic figure skating event. Although featuring stars such as Nancy Kerrigan, it only attracted 150 spectators.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/11/03/sports/tv-sports-for-cbx-figure-skating-is-olympics.html |title=For CBX, Figure Skating Is Olympics |work=[[The New York Times]] |page=3 November 1993 |accessdate=11 December 2011 |archivedate=11 December 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63rPBskeF?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1993/11/03/sports/tv-sports-for-cbx-figure-skating-is-olympics.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The venue has hosted the [[ISU Junior Grand Prix]] in [[1999–2000 ISU Junior Grand Prix|1999–2000]] and [[2000–2001 ISU Junior Grand Prix|2000–01]]{{cite web |url=http://ww2.isu.org/figure/events/9900/jgp79900.html |title=Piruetten 1999 |publisher=[[International Skating Union]] |accessdate=11 December 2011 |archivedate=11 December 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63qpYeuad?url=http://ww2.isu.org/figure/events/9900/jgp79900.html |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}{{cite web |url=http://ww2.isu.org/figure/events/0001/jgp8.html |title=Piruetten 2000 |publisher=[[International Skating Union]] |accessdate=11 December 2011 |archivedate=11 December 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63qpYeuad?url=http://ww2.isu.org/figure/events/9900/jgp79900.html# |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} and the [[World Junior Figure Skating Championships]] in [[2002 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|2002]].{{cite web |url=http://ww2.isu.org/news/jrworlds1.html |title=2002 World Junior Figure Skating Championships: Day 1 |publisher=[[International Skating Union]] |accessdate=11 December 2011 |archivedate=11 December 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63rNOfsU0?url=http://ww2.isu.org/news/jrworlds1.html |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Storhamar Ishall hosted Norway's first international short track speed skating event in November 1991.{{cite news |title=Kortbaneløp på Hamar |agency=[[Norwegian News Agency]] |date=21 November 1991 |language=Norwegian}} The [[1995 World Short Track Speed Skating Championships]] were scheduled to take place at the arena, but were moved to [[Gjøvik Olympic Cavern Hall]] because the Hamar venue would be used by Storhamar Dragons for the play-offs.{{cite news |title=Vil flytte kortbane-VM til Gjøvik |agency=[[Norwegian News Agency]] |date=8 December 1994 |language=Norwegian}} The Olympic Amphitheatre has hosted matches of the [[Norway national handball team|Norway men's national handball team]], with the first tournament being played in January 1993.{{cite news |title=Norge gjorde kort prosess |work=[[Bergens Tidende]] |date=26 January 1993 |page=20 |last=Hagen |first=Vegard Jansen |language=Norwegian}} It has also been used for [[Norway women's national handball team]] matches.{{cite news |title=Håndball: Norsk seier styrket selvtillitten |agency=[[Norwegian News Agency]] |date=30 November 1995 |page=20 |last=Sveum |first=Jan-Erik |language=Norwegian}} The venue was one of seven venues used for the [[1999 World Women's Handball Championship]].{{cite news |title=Håndball: VM-byene klare |date=12 October 1998 |agency=[[Norwegian News Agency]] |language=Norwegian}} Between 2 and 9 December, it hosted nine group-stage matches and three of the quarter-finals. The venue was also the site of two matches during [[Møbelringen Cup 2006]].{{cite web|url=http://www.handball.no/p1.asp?p=11922 |title=Møbelringen Cup 2006 |date=25 November 2006 |publisher=[[Norwegian Handball Federation]] |language=Norwegian |archivedate=24 February 2012 |accessdate=12 December 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224035908/http://www.handball.no/p1.asp?p=11922 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} In September 2007, the Olympic arena hosted [[Fédération Cynologique Internationale]]'s world championship in [[dog agility]].{{cite web|url=http://www.akc.org/events/agility/world/2007/ |title=World Agility Championships |publisher=[[American Kennel Club]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wIOlQ6Nd?url=http://www.idrett.no/nyheter/Documents/YOG2016_Lillehammer_PHOTO.PDF |archivedate=6 February 2011 |accessdate=11 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}{{cite web |url=http://www.agility-wc2007.no/ |title=Welcome to the FCI World Championship in Agility |publisher=FCI Agility World Championships 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415142016/http://www.agility-wc2007.no/ |archivedate=15 April 2009 |accessdate=15 April 2009 |deadurl=no}} The [[2012 IPC Ice Sledge Hockey World Championships]] took place at the Olympic Amphitheatre.{{url=http://kjelkehockey.no/filer/29_12_VMkampoppsett LR.pdf|format=PDF|title=2012 IPC Ice Sledge Hockey World Championships. Hamar – Norway, March 24 – April 1||accessdate=1 April 2011|publisher=[[Norwegian Ice Hockey Federation]]}} Lillehammer hosted the [[2016 Winter Youth Olympics]],{{cite news|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/olympics/youth-olympics/2016/15116-lillehammer-awarded-2016-winter-youth-olympic-games |title=Lillehammer awarded 2016 Winter Youth Olympic Games |work=Inside the Games |date=7 December 2011 |accessdate=7 December 2011 |archivedate=7 December 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63lPt2SIC?url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/olympics/youth-olympics/2016/15116-lillehammer-awarded-2016-winter-youth-olympic-games |df=dmy }} with Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre being the venue for the figure skating events.{{cite web|url=http://www.idrett.no/nyheter/Documents/YOG2016_Lillehammer_PHOTO.PDF |author=[[Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports]] |title=Candidate city for the Winter Youth Olympic Games: Lillehammer 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wIOlQ6Nd?url=http://www.idrett.no/nyheter/Documents/YOG2016_Lillehammer_PHOTO.PDF |archivedate=6 February 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Since 2001, Hamar Olympic Amphitreatre has hosted the annual [[Idrettsgallaen]], a television show that honors the past year's Norwegian sports and athlete achievements. Hamar was selected to host the event because its main sponsor, the national lottery company [[Norsk Tipping]], has its head office in Hamar. Idrettsgallaen is held in early January, when many of winter sports athletes are home and the summer athletes are off season. In 2010, Idrettsgallaen was hosted in Lillehammer because the weekend crashed with the [[2010 European Speed Skating Championships]] in Vikingskipet and Hamar lacks sufficient hotel capacity to host both simultaneously.{{cite web |url=http://www.sportsanalyse.no/wip4/idrettsgallaen-2010-lillehammer/d.epl?id=428796 |title=Idrettsgallaen 2010 til Lillehammer |date=3 April 2009 |last=Unaas |first=Erik |work=Sportsanalyse |accessdate=31 March 2011 |archivedate=10 March 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310084726/http://www.sportsanalyse.no/wip4/idrettsgallaen-2010-lillehammer/d.epl?id=428796 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Concerts hosted at the arena since the opening concert with [[Fats Domino]] on 25 November 1992 include [[Little Richard]] in 1993,{{cite news |title=Little Richard til Hamar |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=28 September 1992 |page=36 |language=Norwegian}} [[Vamp (band)|Vamp]] in 2005,{{cite news |title=Vestlandsfanen |last=Johnsen |first=Lars West |last2=Tostrup |first2=Ivan |work=[[Dagsavisen]] |date=19 November 2005 |page=34 |language=Norwegian}} [[Willie Nelson]] in 2008{{cite news |title=Willie Nelson til Norge |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=22 December 2007 |page=8 |language=Norwegian}} and [[José Carreras]] in 2010.{{cite news |title=Opera-sanger José Carreras under ein konsert i Hamar OL-Amfi søndag |work=[[Vårt Land (Norwegian newspaper)|Vårt Land]] |date=23 July 2010 |page=8 |language=Norwegian}} ==References== {{commons category|Hamar OL-Amfi}} ;Bibliography * {{cite book |title=Norske idrettsanlegg |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digibok_2010042007055 |last=Eriksen |first=Arvid |last2=Greve |first2=Jan |publisher=[[Norwegian Ministry of Culture]] |year=1995 |location=Oslo |isbn=82-90773-06-4 |language=Norwegian}} *{{cite book |last=Gjerdåker |first=Brynjulv |title=Stiftstad og bygdeby. Hamars historie 1935–1991 |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digibok_2008090904023|year=1998 |publisher=Hamar Municipality |location=Hamar |language=Norwegian |isbn=82-994906-1-8}} * {{cite book |title=Byutvikling i Hamar: arkitektur gjennom 150 år |url=http://urn.nb.no/URN:NBN:no-nb_digibok_2010091503016 |last=Hals |first=Anne |publisher=Hedmarksmuseet / Domkirkeodden |year=1999 |location=Hamar |isbn=82-91326-11-8 |language=Norwegian }} * {{cite web|url=http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1994/E_BOOK3.PDF |title=1994 Winter Olympics Report, volume III |author=Lillehammer Olympic Organizing Committee |accessdate=10 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202195006/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1994/E_BOOK3.PDF |archivedate= 2 December 2010 |df= }} * {{cite web|url=http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1994/E_BOOK4.PDF |title=1994 Winter Olympics Report, volume IV |author=Lillehammer Olympic Organizing Committee |accessdate=10 December 2010 revision.text:
The '''Coolflo''' is a [[batting helmet]] designed by [[Rawlings (company)|Rawlings]] and first put into regular use during the [[2006 Major League Baseball season]]. The helmet is designed to allow air to flow through for a more comfortable feel for the hitter. It was previewed during the [[2005 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|2005 All-Star Game]] before being put into regular use. The new helmet was worn by eight teams ([[Chicago Cubs]], [[Los Angeles Dodgers]], [[Anaheim Angels]], [[New York Mets]], [[Tampa Bay Devil Rays]], [[Arizona Diamondbacks]], [[Atlanta Braves]], and [[Baltimore Orioles]]) in 2006 and is now available to all 30 MLB Clubs since 2007. Individual players have the option to wear the new design, but are not required to do so.<ref name="mlb">{{cite press release |title=Rawlings and Major League Baseball® Unveil the New Rawlings® Coolflo™ Batter's Helmet |publisher=[[Rawlings (company)|Rawlings]] |date=April 17, 2006 |url=http://www.rawlings.com/aboutus/press_detail.php?press=Coolflo_MLBPressRelease |accessdate=October 14, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021074632/http://www.rawlings.com/aboutus/press_detail.php?press=Coolflo_MLBPressRelease |archivedate=October 21, 2006 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> As of 2008 there are only four teams who do not have at least one player wearing the helmet: [[Boston Red Sox]], [[Cleveland Indians]], [[New York Yankees]], and [[Washington Nationals]].
The Chicago Cubs abandoned the Coolflo helmets in 2009 because too many of them were breaking.<ref name="lukas">{{cite news |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=lukas/090402 |title=Gold trim, alternate jerseys, bad patches ... must be baseball season - The Uni Watch MLB Season Preview, Page 2 |work=[[ESPN.com]] |date=March 31, 2009 |accessdate=April 15, 2013 | author=Lukas, Paul}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox musical | name = Cricket | subtitle = (Hearts and Wickets) | image = Cricket_musical_poster.gif | image_size = 120 px | caption = | music = [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]] | lyrics = [[Tim Rice]] | book = | basis = | productions = 1986 [[Windsor Castle]]
1986 [[Sydmonton Festival]]
1986 [[Lord's Taverners|Lord's Taverners Ball]] | awards = }} '''''Cricket''''', also called '''''Cricket (Hearts and Wickets)''''', is a short musical written by [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]] and [[Tim Rice]]. It was commissioned for [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth]]'s 60th birthday celebration, and was first performed at [[Windsor Castle]] on 18 June 1986. Several of the tunes from the show were later used for ''[[Aspects of Love]]'', so the work was dropped from public performance or recording.[http://webspace.webring.com/people/oc/camillofan/cricket/musical.html ''Cricket'' – The Musical] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727062109/http://webspace.webring.com/people/oc/camillofan/cricket/musical.html |date=27 July 2011 }}Citron, Stephen. [https://books.google.com/books?id=AWaZ1LAFAZEC&pg=PA355&dq=cricket+musical+%22lloyd+webber%22+rice+ian+%22charleson%22&hl=en&ei=xl7rS5ufH4OOtAOHjKDzDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=cricket%20musical%20%22lloyd%20webber%22%20rice%20ian%20%22charleson%22&f=false ''Sondheim and Lloyd-Webber: The New Musical.''] Oxford University Press, 2001. p. 355. ''Cricket'' was the last original musical Tim Rice and Andrew Lloyd Webber wrote together. ==History== After their collaboration on ''[[Evita (musical)|Evita]]'' in 1978, composer [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]] and lyricist [[Tim Rice]] took what was originally intended to be a temporary break from their illustrious theatrical partnership. They did not work together again until the request for this ''pièce d'occasion'' came up, and ''Cricket'' ended up being their final original musical. [[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex|Prince Edward]], the Queen's youngest son, commissioned a short musical from Lloyd Webber and Rice for his mother's 60th birthday celebration.Snelson, John. [https://books.google.com/books?id=RRFx7fFsi0AC&pg=PA223&dq=%22a+commission+from+Prince+Edward,+The+Queen's+youngest+son%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=PsqDT7etIImriAKar4WABg&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22a%20commission%20from%20Prince%20Edward%2C%20The%20Queen's%20youngest%20son%22&f=false ''Andrew Lloyd Webber'']. Yale University Press, 2009. p. 223. The game of [[cricket]] was Tim Rice's favourite pastime – he had a cricket field on the grounds of his home and had his own cricket teamCitron, Stephen. ''Sondheim and Lloyd-Webber: The New Musical.'' Oxford University Press, 2001. p. 193 – and Rice had a particular passion for this new comic musical about England's national sport. Rice used actual cricket-related names for his characters, boosting the light-hearted feeling of the piece. He and Lloyd Webber created a 25-minute tongue-in-cheek "musicalette" for the Queen. ''Cricket'' is entirely [[sung-through]], with no spoken dialogue. ==Summary== Set against the backdrop of the semi-fictional [[Headingley Stadium#Headingley_Carnegie_Cricket_Ground|Headingley Cricket Club]]'s matches, the comic and slightly melodramatic plot of ''Cricket'' has star player Donald torn between his team and his girlfriend Emma – as she decides to abandon watching cricket for what appears to be a far more exciting life at the race track with the caddish Vincent. The leads in the cast are Donald, Emma, Emma's father, Vincent, and a West Indian [[Fast bowling|fast-bowler]] from the opposing team named Winston B. Packer. The musical's chorus are the rest of the cricket players. ==Synopsis== The show begins during a match of Headingley Cricket Club. The game is watched by the Earl of Headingley, his daughter Emma Kirkstall-Lane, and Vincent St. Leger. The Earl and the cricketers sing the praises of cricket. ("The Summer Game") Emma intends to marry Headingley player Donald Hobbs. And at the moment, even though he is Emma's father, the Earl is more approving of Donald than of Emma, because he feels his daughter is not supportive enough of Donald's cricketing. Emma loves Donald, but she thinks he neglects her somewhat for his cricket playing, and she wants more time together. She feels that she will be forever secondary in Donald's eyes until he retires from cricket. ("As the Seasons Slip Fruitlessly By") Vincent, who is devoted to horse races, overhears Emma, and offers his own rather self-interested solution: leaving for the races in lieu of the cricket match. Emma is reluctant at first, but decides that maybe Vincent is right, and runs off with him. ("The Sport of Kings") The opposing team's [[Fast bowling|fast bowler]], Winston B. Packer, sings about how wonderful it is to be able to hit batsmen when they miss – and he injures several batsmen during the course of the song. ("The Art of Bowling") While Donald is batting, he sees Emma leave with Vincent. He's hurt and truly torn – does he stay and bat to help his team win and lose Emma, or does he leave and try to get her back? In the end, sportsmanship prevails: Donald cannot let his team down. But he has been hit a few times during the song, and is suddenly levelled. As he lies dazed on the ground, lines from various people and various moments of the game bombard him – Winston, Emma, Vincent, his team. ("All I Ask of Life") During the tea interval, Emma returns, dejected, feeling Vincent has deceived her. Not only has she lost all of her money, but she has lost Donald as well. She blames herself, and doesn't see how anyone will ever love her again. ("Fools Like Me") Donald and the cricketers return to the game after the interval, but Donald ignores Emma. The Earl, however, lets fly at Emma and Vincent. Because of Emma's gambling debts, the Earl has lost his reputation and is in financial distress. Vincent tries to speak, but the Earl turns his attention, and wrath, onto him. The Earl is a powerful member of the [[Jockey Club]], and bans Vincent from all racing events for life. Vincent turns to Emma for sympathy, but she accuses him of deceiving her and getting her into trouble with her father. ("A Ban for Life") Vincent and Emma's conversation is cut off by a scream. Wittering has been injured and can no longer continue in the game. Headingley CC needs 10 more runs to win, but there is no one to take Wittering's place alongside Donald. The Earl laments the bad day for Headingley. ("Wittering's Final Innings") Vincent suddenly speaks up and says he will take Wittering's place. ("The Making of St. Leger") He joins Donald and the game continues – to the amazement of the cricketers, who believed Vincent had no redeeming qualities. Vincent is beaten up badly during the game, but keeps playing. Donald's and Vincent's scores win the game and they are both proclaimed heroes. The Earl is so impressed by Vincent's bravery (and recovery of a vital match!) that he withdraws the horse-racing ban. And Donald tells Emma he will play less cricket and spend more time with her. She wonders, could they go to the horse races? Vincent says he will spend Sundays playing cricket. Winston vows to try [[Spin bowling|slow bowling]]. And to top it all off, Wittering is feeling better. ("The Final Stand") Donald and Emma finish making up, and vow to stay together with a sweeping love ballad which ends in a crescendo that everyone joins into, proclaiming the triumph of the cricket metaphor for life and love. ("One Hot Afternoon") ==Songs== * The Summer Game – The Earl, cricketers chorus * As the Seasons Slip Fruitlessly By – Emma * The Sport of Kings – Vincent, Emma * The Art of Bowling – Winston B. Packer * All I Ask of Life – Donald * Fools Like Me – Emma and cricketers * A Ban for Life – the Earl and Vincent; Emma * Wittering's Final Innings – Cricketers, the Earl, Wittering * The Making of St. Leger – Vincent; All * The Final Stand – the Earl and cricketers; All * One Hot Afternoon – Donald and Emma; All ==Productions== The show debuted as planned on 18 June 1986 at Windsor Castle, directed by [[Trevor Nunn]] and starring [[Ian Charleson]], [[Sarah Payne (actor)|Sarah Payne]], and [[John Savident]]. The musicians were members of [[Colosseum II]] and others – the ensemble that had first performed Lloyd Webber's ''[[Variations (Andrew Lloyd Webber album)|Variations]]''. The men's vocal group [[Cantabile (group)|Cantabile]] played the cricketers' chorus. The Windsor Castle performance was quite spirited and amusing, and was very well received. Two more performances followed. One was at Lloyd Webber's [[Sydmonton Festival]] on 15 July 1986. The last performance was in November 1986 at Tim Rice's favourite charity, the [[Lord's Taverners|Lord's Taverners Ball]], where Rice played the cricketer Wittering, dressed in his own Heartaches Cricket Club[http://www.heartaches.co.uk/ Heartaches Cricket Club] uniform. A segment of the original rehearsals of ''Cricket'' was televised on the Andrew Lloyd Webber instalment of ''[[The South Bank Show]]'', which aired on 15 November 1986. The segment featured Sarah Payne and Alvin Stardust rehearsing "As the Seasons Slip Fruitlessly By" and "The Sport of Kings". There have been no further performances of the musical. ==Original cast== *[[Ian Charleson]] – Donald Hobbs, devoted cricketer for Headingley Cricket Club *[[Sarah Payne (actor)|Sarah Payne]] – Emma Kirkstall-Lane, Donald's girlfriend *[[John Savident]] – the Earl of Headingley, Emma's father, the solicitous patron of the Headingley Cricket Club, and a Steward of the [[Jockey Club]] *[[Alvin Stardust]] – Vincent St. Leger, a caddish fellow who spends his time betting at horse races *[[George Harris (actor)|George Harris]] – Winston B. Packer, a lethal [[fast bowling|fast bowler]] originally from the [[West Indies]] *[[Cantabile (group)|Cantabile]] – Chorus of cricketers *[[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex|HRH Prince Edward]] – Wittering, the gallant last [[batsman]] for Headingley Cricket Club ==After 1986== Lloyd Webber used at least five of the tunes from ''Cricket'' in his musical ''[[Aspects of Love]]'' (1989). This meant that ''Cricket'', which had been extremely well received, was a dead item, a fact that greatly distressed Tim Rice. The piece could thus never be expanded into a full theatrical musical. Lloyd Webber used other tunes from ''Cricket'' in ''[[Sunset Boulevard (musical)|Sunset Boulevard]]''. The ''Cricket'' libretto was published in '''A Breathless Hush ...': The MCC Anthology of Cricket Verse'' (2004). ''Cricket'' has not been recorded for commercial release, although a non-commercial instrumental demo studio album was recorded on solo piano in 1986.[http://castalbumcollector.com/recordings/6803 ''Cricket'' demo recording] at CastAlbumCollector.com The performance rights for the piece have not yet been made available. The men's vocal group [[Cantabile (group)|Cantabile]] recorded "The Summer Game", featuring [[Tim Rice]] singing as the Earl, on their 2011 CD ''Songs of Cricket''.[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B005BAKU3Q ''Songs of Cricket''] – CD by [[Cantabile (group)|Cantabile]] {{cquote|''Let them hurl their worst my way
None can break my wicket or my heart''|30px|30px|Donald, "All I Ask of Life"}} ==References== *[http://www.timrice.co.uk/cricket2.html Sir Tim Rice – ''Cricket''] *Allen, David R. and [[Hubert Doggart]] (eds). [https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0413772152 '''A Breathless Hush ...': The MCC Anthology of Cricket Verse''.] London: [[Methuen Publishing|Methuen]], 2004. pp. 331–343. ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} {{Navboxes | title = Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice | list = {{Lloyd Webber and Rice}} {{Andrew Lloyd Webber}} {{Tim Rice}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cricket (Musical)}} [[Category:1986 musicals]] [[Category:Compositions by Andrew Lloyd Webber]] [[Category:Musicals by Tim Rice]] [[Category:Musicals by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice]] [[Category:One-act musicals]] [[Category:Sung-through musicals]] [[Category:Cricket culture]] [[Category:Sports in art]] [[Category:British musicals]]

{{Expand Spanish|Estadio Panamericano|date=December 2014}} {{refimprove|auto=yes|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox venue | name = Estadio Panamericano | image = [[File:Estadio Panamericano Cuba.png|300px]] | location = [[Havana]], [[Cuba]] | opened = 1991 | capacity = 50,000 | tenants = }} '''Estadio Panamericano''' (Stade Panaméricain de La Havane) is a multi-use [[stadium]] located near [[Cojimar]], a city ward of [[Havana]], [[Cuba]]. It is used mostly for [[athletics (sport)|athletics]], [[baseball]] and alternate site for the [[Cuba national football team]]. ==History== It was first used as the main stadium for the [[1991 Pan American Games]]. The stadium opened August 1, 1991 and is able to hold 34,000 people (can have expanded capacity to 50,000).[http://www.lonelyplanet.com/americas/cuba/havana/outer-havana/cojimar-area/sights/sporting-venues/estadio-panamericano Estadio Panamericano on lonelyplanet.com] It served as the site of an episode of the American version of [[Top Gear (U.S. TV series)|Top Gear]] in 2016. The episode showed the stadium in disrepair and mostly abandoned. ===Renovations=== The stadium was renovated in 2008 with an artificial turf replacing the original grass turf. ==Structure== The stadium is surrounded by a park and faces nearby Boca de [[Cojimar]] ([[Havana Bay]]). Seating is mainly open air with a partially covered grandstand to the east side. Surrounding the football field is an oval track. ==See also== *[[Estadio Latinoamericano]] *[[Estadio Pedro Marrero]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat-inline|Estadio Panamericano}} {{Start box}} {{Succession box | title=[[Pan American Games]]
Opening and Closing Ceremonies| before=[[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]]
[[Indianapolis]]| after=[[Estadio José María Minella]]
[[Mar del Plata]]| years=[[1991 Pan American Games|1991]] }} {{End box}} {{Pan American Games stadiums}} {{Coord|23|9|27|N|82|19|00|W|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Football venues in Cuba]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Cuba]] [[Category:Sports venues in Havana]] [[Category:Pan American Games opening ceremony stadiums]] [[Category:Pan American Games athletics venues]] [[Category:Venues of the 1991 Pan American Games]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1991]] {{Cuba-sports-venue-stub}}

{{More citations needed|date=April 2018}}{{Infobox venue | name = | nickname = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | fullname = | former names = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | pushpin_map = USA North Carolina | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = Location within [[North Carolina]] | pushpin_label_position = right | address = 300 Stadium St SW, Wilson, NC 27893 | location = [[Wilson, North Carolina|Wilson]], [[North Carolina]] | coordinates = {{Coord|35.718382|-77.930338|display=inline}} | type = | genre = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = {{start date|1939}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = Yes | production = | cost = | architect = | builder = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = 3000 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = Left field: 332 ft
Center field: 405 ft
Right field: 332 ft | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Wilson Tobs]] | embedded = | website = | publictransit = }} '''Fleming Stadium''' is a sports [[stadium]] in [[Wilson, North Carolina]]. It is primarily used for [[baseball]] and is the home of the [[Wilson Tobs]] of the [[Coastal Plain League]]. It opened in 1939 and has a capacity of 3,000 people. The grounds are also home to the North Carolina Baseball Museum. It also has bricks with names of the donors right in front of the museum. The stadium has been used by teams in several different minor leagues over the decades, including the Class D [[Coastal Plain League (Class D)|Coastal Plain League]], the [[Bi-State League]], and the [[Carolina League]].{{cite book|author=Chris Epting|title=Roadside Baseball: The Locations of America's Baseball Landmarks|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OpCPBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT185|year=2009|publisher=Santa Monica Press|isbn=978-1-59580-911-7|page=185}} The [[Carolina Mudcats (1991–2011)|Carolina Mudcats]] used the ballpark as their temporary home in 1991, before opening [[Five County Stadium]] at [[Zebulon, North Carolina|Zebulon]] in mid-season. == North Carolina Baseball Museum== The '''North Carolina Baseball Museum''' is a museum located in Wilson, North Carolina that honors those past and present [[Major League Baseball]] players and [[Negro league baseball|Negro League]] players from the state of North Carolina. The museum contains vintage baseball cards, memorabilia, books, and other baseball memorabilia. The museum has a main focus on 7 National Baseball Hall of Famers that were born in North Carolina. These players include [[Luke Appling]], [[Rick Ferrell]], [[Catfish Hunter|Jim "Catfish" Hunter]], [[Gaylord Perry]], [[Buck Leonard]], [[Enos Slaughter]], and [[Hoyt Wilhelm|Hoyt Wilheim]]. A separate room contains baseball memorabilia of the state's colleges and local high schools. The museum also provides focus on Negro League players such as Buck Leonard and [[women in baseball]]. Other signed memorabilia can also been seen throughout the museum. The museum hosts an annual Hot Stove Dinner as a fundraiser. The first speaker of the annual dinner was [[Stan Musial]]. The museum is located at Fleming Stadium which is the home of [[Wilson Tobs]], a collegiate summer league team in the Coastal Plain League. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://wilsontobs.com/fleming_stadium/history/ Info about the ballpark] *[http://ncbaseballmuseum.com/ North Carolina Baseball Museum] *[http://www.wral.com/baseball-memories-find-home-at-fleming-stadium/13558864/ 2014 TV story about the ballpark's 75th anniversary] {{CPL Ballparks}} [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Wilson, North Carolina]] [[Category:Baseball venues in North Carolina]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Wilson County, North Carolina]] [[Category:1939 establishments in North Carolina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1939]] [[Category:Museums in Wilson County, North Carolina|North Carolina Baseball Museum]] [[Category:Baseball museums and halls of fame|North Carolina Baseball Museum]] {{NorthCarolina-baseball-venue-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Use Scottish English|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox organization |name = Gannochy Trust |image = |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |map2 = |abbreviation = |motto = |predecessor = none |successor = n/a |formation = 21 June 1937<!-- {{Start date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> |founder = Arthur Kinmond Bell |extinction = |type = Charity |status = Registered Charity |purpose = To make a positive difference for the benefit of people living in Scotland, with a preference for Perth & Kinross |headquarters = Pitcullen Crescent, Perth |location = Scotland |coords = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> |region_served = |membership = |language = |general = |leader_title = Chairman |leader_name = Dr James Kynaston |leader_title2 = Chief Executive |leader_name2 = Carol Downie MBE |leader_title3 = |leader_name3 = |leader_title4 = |leader_name4 = |key_people = Trustees |main_organ = Board of Trustees |parent_organization = |affiliations = |budget = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = 14 |Website = [http://www.gannochytrust.org.uk/index.php?page=home www.gannochytrust.org.uk]<!-- {{URL|example.org}} --> |remarks = |former name = none }} The '''Gannochy trust''' is a Scottish [[Scottish charity|charity]] with a preference for projects in [[Perth and Kinross]]. The trust was founded in 1937 by influential [[Perth, Scotland|Perth]] business man [[Arthur Kinmond Bell]], known as A. K. Bell, of [[Arthur Bell & Sons Ltd]].
==History== The Gannochy Trust was founded in 1937, by the established whisky distiller and philanthropist [[AK Bell|A. K. Bell]].<ref name="Welsh2011">{{Cite news | last = Welsh| first = Andrew | title = Perth good cause Gannochy Trust's 75th anniversary| work = Daily Record| date = 9 December 2011|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/local-news/perth-good-cause-gannochy-trusts-2732979 |accessdate = 12 September 2013}}</ref> The founding aims of the project were to maintain the Gannochy Housing estate, built by A. K. Bell, and to continue to improve [[Perth, Scotland|Perth]] and the surrounding area for the local citizens into the future. Initially this was funded from shares in [[Bell's whisky|Bell's Whisky]], gifted to the trust by their founder.<ref name="Bell and Trust">{{cite web|title=A K Bell and the Gannochy Trust|url=http://www.gannochytrust.org.uk/index.php?page=a-k-bell|website=GannochyTrust|publisher=Gannochy Trust|accessdate=13 July 2014}}</ref>
==Activities==
The Trust funds many activities in [[Scotland]], with a preference for [[Perth and Kinross]], through awarding grants to what it feels are worthwhile causes. It has four over-arching themes with grant applications expected to meet at least one of the following aims, although the third and fourth will only be accepted for projects within Perth and Kinross:<ref name="Grant Directory">{{cite book|title=The Directory of Grant Making Trusts - 2012/13|date=2012|publisher=Directory of Social Change|location=London|isbn=978-1-906294-56-4|edition=22nd}}</ref>
* Inspiring young people * Improving the quality of life for disadvantaged and vulnerable people * Supporting and developing amenities for communities * Caring for the natural and man made environments
The Gannochy trust particularly provides many grants for the improvement of sports provision and participation.<ref>{{cite web| title =Sportscotland page for Gannochy Trust| url =http://www.sportscotland.org.uk/funding/Funding_finder/Gannochy_Trust| date = 29 October 2012| accessdate = 12 September 2013}}</ref>
In line with the original [[Trust instrument|Trust Deed]], the trust also manages and rents property in the Gannochy area of Perth. This includes an estate of rented homes, a mixture of general and sheltered housing, as well as a small number of farms. The trust also manage the nearby Doo'cot Cricket Park, and Quarrymill park, as places for community recreation.<ref>Duncan 2012 {{ndash}} pp53-56</ref>
==Partnerships==
To help meet the goals stated above, the Trust has helped form a number of charitable partnerships, often in conjunction with [[Perth and Kinross Council]], to help it distribute funds to where they are needed while maintaining its charitable status.<ref>Duncan 2012 {{ndash}} p. 67</ref>
The first such partnership was Bell’s Sports Centre (Perth) Ltd set up to run the sports centre built by the Trust.<ref>Duncan 2012 {{ndash}} p66</ref> Now known as Live Active Leisure Ltd, this body has grown to include many recreational venues across the county.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our History|url=http://www.liveactive.co.uk/our-background|website=Live Active|accessdate=1 August 2014}}</ref>
A later partnership was the Perth and Kinross Countryside Trust, which helps maintain the rural walkways and other amenities meeting the objectives of caring for the natural environment.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our Partners |url=http://www.pkct.org/our-story/partners |website=Perth & Kinross Countryside Trust |accessdate=1 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808041504/http://www.pkct.org/our-story/partners |archivedate=8 August 2014 |df= }}</ref>
Another such partnership is the Perth and Kinross Heritage Trust, which conserves the archaeological and architectural heritage of Perth.<ref>{{cite web|title=2011-2012 Annual Report |url=http://www.pkht.org.uk/perch/resources/pkht-annual-report-2011-12.pdf |website=Perth and Kinross Heritage Trust |accessdate=1 August 2014 |location=Perth |page=2 |year=2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130806172128/http://www.pkht.org.uk/perch/resources/pkht-annual-report-2011-12.pdf |archivedate=6 August 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==Notable projects==
===Within Perthshire===
In line with A K Bell's intentions, the Gannochy Trust has played a large role in the development of modern day Perth, and it has been noted that many of the landmarks visible to visitors today are a result of the support of the Trust.<ref name="Perth's_tribute">{{cite news||title=Perth's Tribute to A. K. Bell extract made available at RootsWeb|url=http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/SANDEMAN/2004-10/1097742672|accessdate=16 July 2014|work=Courier and Advertiser|agency=Courier and Advertiser|date=4 July 1994}}</ref>
One of the first major projects for the trust was the construction of the Bell's Sports Center in Perth, announced in December 1964 and construction starting in March 1967 with the Gannochy Trust providing £225,000 towards the costs of construction.<ref>Duncan 2012 {{ndash}} pp. 43-44</ref> The center opened in 1968.<ref name= BriefHistory>{{cite web|last1=Lambert|first1=Tim|title=A Brief History of Perth| url=http://www.localhistories.org/perth.html |website=localhistories.org|accessdate=31 July 2014}}</ref> They also provided funding for refurbishments and extensions in 1972 and 1982, with the newly extended center being renamed the Gannochy Sports Complex, although the Bell's Sports Center is still the most commonly used name for the complex.<ref>Duncan 2012 {{ndash}} p65</ref>
The Trust has also supported the [[Perth Theatre]] and recently helped secure £14.5 million in funding for a two-year refurbishment project.<ref>{{Cite news| title = Two-year closure during £14.5m Perth Theatre transformation| work = [[The Courier (Dundee)|The Courier]] |location=Dundee, Scotland | date = 21 August 2013| url = http://www.thecourier.co.uk/news/local/perth-kinross/two-year-closure-during-14-5m-perth-theatre-transformation-1.122496| accessdate = 12 September 2013}}</ref> This project was scheduled to start in the summer of 2014 and is expected to be completed by spring 2017 with the intention of restoring and extending the Edwardian building to better serve the city.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lowson|first1=Alison|title=Perth Theatre redevelopment starts this summer|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/local-news/perth-theatre-redevelopment-starts-summer-3457485|accessdate=1 August 2014|work=Daily Record|date=25 April 2014}}</ref>
In 1994 it was announced that Perth's a new multi-million pound library would be named the A K Bell Library. This was both in recognition of the fact that the Gannochy Trust was a major contributor to this project, as well as the large role they, and their founder A K Bell, have made to the City since its foundation.<ref name="Perth's_tribute" /> The library was formally opened in 1995.<ref name=BriefHistory />
===Within the rest of Scotland===
In 1967, as part of the construction of [[Stirling University]], the Gannochy Trust provided up to £100,000 towards a sports pavilion on the campus. They have continued to support sport at the university, including funding sports bursaries in 1983, and contributing £500,000 to the Scottish National Tennis Centre in 1989.<ref>Duncan 2012 {{ndash}} p75</ref>
Between 2003 and 2010, The Gannochy Trust sponsored the Gannochy Trust Innovation Award, awarded in by the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. This highly prestigious award was awarded to an individual in Scotland under the age of 45 in recognition of outstanding achievement which had resulted in a major economic or social benefit to Scotland or the wider world.<ref>Duncan 2012 {{ndash}} p76</ref> This award consisted of a gold medal and £50,000 to develop the idea, and it is believed the £600,000 awarded has created £4 million of additional value to the Scottish economy.<ref>{{Cite web | title = The Gannochy Trust Innovation Award| publisher = The Royal Society of Edinburgh| date = |url = http://www.royalsoced.org.uk/806_TheGannochyTrustInnovationAward.html| accessdate = 13 September 2013}}</ref>
{{Portal bar|Scotland}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
===Works cited=== *Duncan 2012 {{ndash}} {{cite book|last1=Duncan|first1=Jeremy|title=A Roof Over One's Head|date=2012|publisher=Farquhar and Son Ltd|location=Perth|isbn=978-0-9560620-7-9}}
==External links== * [http://www.gannochytrust.org.uk/ Organisation Website]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Gyumri City Stadium
Գյումրիի քաղաքային մարզադաշտ | image = [[File:Gyumri city stadium, 24 Octobe 2015.jpg|300px|center|Gyumri City Stadium in 2012]] | caption = Gyumri City Stadium | location = [[Gyumri]], [[Armenia]] | built = 1924 | opened = | renovated = 1999, 2012 | owner = Gyumri City Council | seating_capacity = 2,844 | surface = [[grass]] | dimensions = 105 x 68 meters | tenants = [[FC Shirak|Shirak]] (1958-present)
[[FC Shirak#Shirak-2|Shirak-2]] (2017-present) }} {{Coord|40|47|09|N|43|50|00|E|type:landmark|display=title}} '''Gyumri City Stadium''' ({{lang-hy|Գյումրիի քաղաքային մարզադաշտ}}) is an [[all-seater stadium|all-seater]] [[association football|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Gyumri]], [[Armenia]]. It is currently the home venue of the [[Armenian Premier League]] club [[FC Shirak]] of Gyumri. The capacity of the stadium is 2,844 seats, excluding the standing section at the southern end of the pitch.{{cite web | url = http://www.football365.am/wp/?p=5535 | script-title=hy:Գյումրին պատրաստ է ընդունել ֆուտբոլային տոնը | date = 2012-04-21 | publisher = Ֆուտբոլ 365 | accessdate = July 7, 2012|language=hy}} ==History== The stadium was built and opened in 1924 to become the first stadium in the modern history of Armenia. When [[FC Shirak|Shirak]] was founded in 1958, the stadium became the regular home ground of the team for the [[Soviet First League]] competition. Starting from 1991, the stadium witnessed many glorious moments of FC Shirak in the [[Armenian Premier League]] and the [[Armenian Independence Cup]]. The stadium hosted the [[2011–12 Armenian Cup]] final match when Shirak defeated [[Impulse FC|Impulse]] to win the title for the first time in their history. [[File:Gyumri city stadium after renovation.jpg|thumb|left|The main stand]] The venue was reconstructed in 1999 and turned into an all-seater stadium. The total capacity of the stadium became 2,844 seats (1,413 at the western stand and 1,431 at the eastern stand). During 2012, the playing pitch and many other facilities were entirely renovated to meet the [[UEFA]] standards. As of 2014, the stadium is the home ground of Shirak for the domestic competitions since 1958. However, after the most recent developments in 2012, the stadium was permitted to be used by the club for their home games at the European competitions. On 12 July 2012, Shirak hosted [[FK Rudar Pljevlja|Rudar Pljevlja]] at the Gyumri City Stadium, in the [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League qualifying phase and play-off round|qualifying phase]] of the [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League]]. The match ended in a 1-1 draw, allowing FC Shirak to advance with a 2-1 win on aggregate. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Shirak F.C.}} {{Armenian Premier League venues}} {{Football venues in Armenia}} {{Gyumri}} [[Category:Shirak SC]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1924]] [[Category:Sports venues built in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Football venues in Armenia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Gyumri]]
